1.text: Then the Pharisees and some of the scribes came from Jerusalem and gathered to [see] Jesus.

2.text: When they saw that some of his disciples were eating bread with defiled (that is, unwashed) hands, they found fault.

3.text: (For the Pharisees and all the Jews hold to the tradition of the presbyters and do not eat unless they wash their hands and forearms.

4.text: [Also], they do not eat when they return from the marketplace unless they [first] bathe themselves; and there are many other things which they have received and observe: washings of cups, pitchers, bronze vessels, and couches.)

5.text: Then the Pharisees and the scribes asked him, “Why is it that your disciples do not live by the tradition of the presbyters, but eat their bread with unwashed hands?”

6.text: Jesus answered them, “Well did Isaias (Isaiah) prophesy of you hypocrites, as it is written:  ‘This people honors me with their lips,   but their heart is far from me.

7.text: And in vain do they express adoration before me,   teaching as doctrines the commandments of men.’

8.text: Indeed, you set aside the commandment of God and hold fast to human tradition—the washing of pitchers and cups, and you do many other such things.”

9.text: He said to them, “How ingeniously do you reject the commandment of God in order to keep your tradition!

10.text: For Moses said, ‘Honor your father and your mother;’ and, ‘Whoever speaks evil of father or mother should be put to death.’

11.text: But you say, ‘If a man tells his father or mother, “Whatever [support] you might have received from me is Corban (that is, dedicated to God)”’

12.text: then you no longer allow him to do anything for his father or mother.

13.text: Thus, you nullify the word of God by your tradition which you have handed down. And you do many [other] things like this.”

14.text: Jesus called the entire crowd to himself and said to them, “Hear me, all of you, and understand!

15.text: There is nothing outside a person that by going in can defile; it is what comes out that defiles the person.

16.text: Anyone who has ears for listening should listen!”

17.text: When he had entered into a house away from the crowd, his disciples asked him about the parable.

18.text: He said to them, “Are you also without understanding? Do you not yet perceive that whatever goes into someone from the outside cannot defile that person

19.text: because it does not go into his heart but into the stomach, and then into the sewer (thus he declared all foods to be clean)?”

20.text: He said, “What comes out of a person is what defiles that person.

21.text: Indeed, it is from within, out of human hearts, that evil thoughts proceed: adultery, sexual immorality, murder, theft,

22.text: greed, wickedness, deceit, lustful desires, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, and foolishness.

23.text: All these evil things come from within and make a person unclean.”

24.text: From there, he arose and went away to the borders of Tyre and Sidon. He entered a house and did not want anyone to know it, yet he could not escape notice.

25.text: Having heard about Jesus, a woman whose little daughter had an unclean spirit came and fell down at his feet.

26.text: Now this woman was a Greek, of Syro-Phoenician descent. She begged him to cast the demon out of her daughter.

27.text: But Jesus said to her, “Let the children be filled first, for it is not right to take the children’s bread and to throw it to the little dogs!”

28.text: But she answered, “Yes, Lord. Yet even the dogs under the table eat the children’s crumbs!”

29.text: Jesus said to her, “For saying this, you may go your way! The demon has gone out of your daughter.”

30.text: She went away to her house and found the child lying on the bed, the demon having gone out.

31.text: Again, Jesus departed from the borders of Tyre and Sidon, and came to the sea of Galilee, passing through the region of the Decapolis.

32.text: And [some] people brought him a person who was deaf and had an impediment in his speech, and they begged Jesus to lay his hand on him.

33.text: And taking him aside from the crowd, in private, he put his fingers into the man’s ears, then spat and touched his tongue.

34.text: Looking up to heaven, Jesus sighed and said to him, “Ephphatha!” that is, “Be opened!”

35.text: Immediately, the man’s ears were opened; the impediment of his tongue was released, and he spoke clearly.

36.text: Jesus told the people to tell no one, but the more he ordered them, the more widely they proclaimed it.

37.text: They were amazed beyond words, saying, “Everything he has done is good! He even makes the deaf hear, and the mute speak!”
